standard_metadata.standard_description: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.

images.alt: Three lines intersecting each others at one point, the angles on one of the lines are labeled as 25 degrees, and 80 degrees and on the second line the two angles are labeled as 80 degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are vertical angles because they are angles opposite each other where two lines cross.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three lines intersecting each others at one point, the angles opposite to each other are labeled as 25 degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: Vertical angles are equivalent.
$x = 25^\circ$

images.alt: A pentagon having 3 diagonals. Two with the top vertex and the third diagonal is parallel to the horizontal line at bottom of the pentagon. The third diagonal is having two obtuse angles equal to 100 degrees and the third acute angle is opposite to the one of the 100 degrees angles, labeled as X degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are vertical angles because they are angles opposite each other where two lines cross.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A pentagon having 3 diagonals. Two with the top vertex and the third diagonal is parallel to the horizontal line at bottom of the pentagon. The third diagonal is having one obtuse angle equal to 100 degrees and the second angle is opposite to the 100 degrees angles, labeled as X degrees.

hints.content: Vertical angles are equivalent.

images.alt: Two parallel lines intersected by a transversal at two points. The transversal and the lower parallel line make Two opposite obtuse angles labeled as X degrees and 145 degrees. The adjacent angle to angle x is labeled as 35 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are vertical angles because they are angles opposite each other where two lines cross.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two parallel lines intersected by a transversal at two points. The transversal and the lower parallel line make Two opposite obtuse angles labeled as X degrees and 145 degrees.

hints.content: Vertical angles are equivalent.

images.alt: Two slant lines and the horizontal line are intersecting each other. One of the slant lines with the horizontal line is creating obtuse angle labeled as 155 degrees. And the other slant line with the horizontal line is creating acute angles labeled as 35 degrees and x degrees opposite to each other.

hints.content: The angles marked below are vertical angles because they are angles opposite each other where two lines cross.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two slant lines and the horizontal line are intersecting each others. One of the slant lines with the horizontal line is creating acute angles labeled as 35 degrees and X degrees opposite to each other.

hints.content: Vertical angles are equivalent.
$x = 35^\circ$

images.alt: A quadrilateral with two diagonals. The intersecting point on the diagonals making angles 95 degrees and X degrees opposite to each other. One of the four angles of the quadrilateral is labeled as 60 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are vertical angles because they are angles opposite each other where two lines cross.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A quadrilateral with two diagonals. The intersecting point on the diagonals making angles 95 degrees and X degrees opposite to each other.

hints.content: Vertical angles are equivalent.
$x = 95^\circ$

images.alt: Two lines intersect each other creating obtuse angles labeled x and 100 degrees. A ray intersects one of the acute angles, and creates an angle labeled 45 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are vertical angles because they are angles opposite each other where two lines cross.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two lines intersect each other creating obtuse angles labeled x and 100 degrees. A ray intersects one of the acute angles and creates an angle labeled 45 degrees.

hints.content: Vertical angles are equivalent.

images.alt: A pentagon having 3 diagonals. Two with the top vertex and the third diagonal is parallel to the horizontal line at bottom of the pentagon. The third diagonal is having two obtuse angles equal to 100 degrees and the third acute angle is supplementary angle of the 100 degrees angle, labeled as X degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A pentagon having 3 diagonals. Two with the top vertex and the third diagonal is parallel to the horizontal line at bottom of the pentagon. The third diagonal is having one obtuse angle and one acute angle equal to 100 degrees and X degrees respectively. Both angles are supplementary angles.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{100^\circ} + \greenD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \greenD{\angle x} &=  80^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Two slant lines and the horizontal line are intersecting each others. One of the slant lines creating supplementary angles labeled as 165 degrees and X degrees. And the other slant line with the horizontal line is creating an obtuse angle labeled as 145 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two slant lines and the horizontal line are intersecting each others One of the slant lines creating supplementary angles labeled as 165 degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{165^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  15^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: A parallelogram having two diagonals. The intersecting point on the diagonals is making angles 90 degrees and X degrees supplement to each other. The half of the one of the four angles, of the parallelogram is labeled as 30 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A parallelogram having two diagonals. The intersecting point on the diagonals, is making angles 90 degrees and X degrees supplement to each other.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{90^\circ} + \greenD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \greenD{\angle x} &=  90^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: A straight horizontal line intersected by a diagonal line, forming a 35 degrees angle and another angle labeled X degrees. The intersection creates an implied 180 degrees angle along the horizontal line, with 35 degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A straight horizontal line intersected by a diagonal line, forming a 35 degrees angle and another angle labeled X degrees. The intersection creates an implied 180 degrees angle along the horizontal line, with 35 degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\greenD{35^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  145^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Two parallel lines intersected by a diagonal line. The intersection creates several angles. On the upper parallel line, the angle on the left side of the diagonal is labeled as 33 degrees. Below, the diagonal on the lower parallel line, the angle on the left side is labeled X degrees and angle adjacent to it is labeled 33 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two parallel lines intersected by a diagonal line. The intersection creates several angles. On the upper parallel line, the angle on the left side of the diagonal is labeled as 33 degrees. Below, the diagonal on the lower parallel line, the angle on the left side is labeled X degrees and angle adjacent to it is labeled 33 degrees.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{33^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  147^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersecting at a single point. One of the slant line are creating supplementary angles of X degrees and 120 degrees. And the other side of this slant line creating supplementary angles of 90 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersecting at a single point. One of the slant line are creating supplementary angles of X degrees and 120 degrees. And the other side of this slant line creating 90 degrees angle.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\greenD{120^\circ} + \blueD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \blueD{\angle x} &=  60^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Three lines intersecting each others at one point, are labeled with four angles from the left as 125 degrees, X degrees, 35 degrees and 90 degrees in clockwise order.

hints.content: The angles marked below are supplementary angles because they lie on the same side of a straight line.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three lines intersecting each others at one point, are labeled with three angles as 125 degrees, X degrees and 90 degrees.

hints.content: Supplementary angles add up to $180 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\greenD{125^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  180^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  55^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: A straight horizontal line is perpendicular to a straight vertical ray. One of the two angles made by the line and the ray is divided into unequal parts by another ray. The measurements of these unequal angles are 25 degrees and X degrees. The other side of the line is creating 180 degrees angle.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A straight horizontal line is perpendicular to a straight vertical ray. One of the two angles made by the line and the ray is divided into unequal parts by another ray. The measurements of these unequal angles are 25 degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\greenD{25^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  65^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: A straight line with two angles formed on one side by an intersecting line. The intersecting line makes an angle of 90 degrees with the straight line. The straight line is labeled with an angle of 180 degrees. On the right side of the intersection, there is an angle labeled 35 degrees, and on the left side, the adjacent angle is labeled with X degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A straight line with two angles formed on one side by an intersecting line. The intersecting line makes an angle of 90 degrees with the straight line. The straight line is labeled with an angle of 180 degrees. On the right side of the intersection, there is an angle labeled 35 degrees, and on the left side, the adjacent angle is labeled with X degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{35^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  55^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersecting at a single point. One of the slant line are creating angles X degrees, 30 degrees, and 90 degrees. And the other slant line creating 30 degrees, and 150 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersecting at a single point. One of the slant line are creating angles X degrees, 30 degrees, and 90 degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\greenD{30^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  60^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: A slant line with 3 rays intersecting at one point creating two angles labeled as 120 degrees, and 90 degrees. Further 90 degrees angle is divided into two angles labeled as X degrees and 32 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A slant line with 3 rays intersecting at one point creating two angles labeled as 120 degrees, and 90 degrees. Further 90 degrees angle is divided into two angles labeled as X degrees and 32 degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{32^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  58^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: A square labeled with 90 degrees of each angle. The square is divided into two parts by a diagonal. The diagonal also splits a right angle into two angles. One is labeled as 45 degrees and other with X degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square labeled with 90 degrees of each angle. The square is divided into two parts by a diagonal. The diagonal also splits a right angle into two angles. One is labeled as 45 degrees and other with X degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{45^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  45^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Three lines intersecting each others at one point, the angles on one of the lines are labeled as X degrees, 28 degrees and 90 degrees. And the other line is having angles labeled as 28 degrees, 152 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Three lines intersecting each others at one point, the angles on one of the lines are labeled as X degrees, 28 degrees and 90 degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\blueD{28^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  62^\circ \end{align}$

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersecting at a single point. One of the slant line are creating supplementary angles of 90 degrees, X degrees and 26 degrees. And the other side of this slant line creating supplementary angles of 180 degrees.

hints.content: The angles marked below are complementary angles because they form a right angle.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersecting at a single point. One of the slant line are creating supplementary angles of 90 degrees, X degrees and 26 degrees.

hints.content: Complementary angles add up to $90 ^\circ$.   $\begin{align}\greenD{26^\circ} + \goldD{\angle x}  &=  90^\circ  \\\\ \goldD{\angle x} &=  64^\circ \end{align}$
